Problems and conditioning

Let’s think a bit about what must be the easiest math problem you’ve dealt with in quite some time: adding 1 to a number. Formally, we describe this problem as a function f(x)=x+1f(x)=x+1f(x)=x+1, where xxx is any real number.

On a computer, xxx will be represented by its floating-point counterpart, fl⁡(x)\fl(x)fl(x). Given the property (1.1.5), we have fl⁡(x)=x(1+ϵ)\fl(x)=x(1+\epsilon)fl(x)=x(1+ϵ) for some ε satisfying ∣ϵ∣<ϵmach/2|\epsilon| < \macheps/2∣ϵ∣<ϵmach​/2. There is no error in representing the value 1.

Let’s suppose that we are fortunate and that the addition proceeds exactly, with no additional errors. Then the machine result is just

y=x(1+ϵ)+1. {y} = x(1+\epsilon)+1.y=x(1+ϵ)+1.
(1.2.1)

We can derive the relative error in this result:

∣y−f(x)∣∣f(x)∣=∣(x+ϵx+1)−(x+1)∣∣x+1∣=∣ϵx∣∣x+1∣. \frac{ |{y}-f(x)| }{ |f(x)| } = \frac{ |(x+\epsilon x+1) - (x+1)| }{ |x+1| } = \frac{ |\epsilon x| }{ |x+1| } .∣f(x)∣∣y−f(x)∣​=∣x+1∣∣(x+ϵx+1)−(x+1)∣​=∣x+1∣∣ϵx∣​.
(1.2.2)

This error could be quite large if the denominator is small. In fact, we can make the relative error as large as we please by taking xxx very close to -1. This is essentially what happened in Demo 1.1.4.

You may have encountered this situation before when using significant digits for scientific calculations. Suppose we round all results to five decimal digits, and we add -1.0012 to 1.0000. The result is -0.0012, or −1.2×10−3-1.2\times 10^{-3}−1.2×10−3 in scientific notation. Notice that even though both operands are specified to five digits, it makes no sense to write more than two digits in the answer because there is no information in the problem beyond their decimal places.

This phenomenon is known as subtractive cancellation, or loss of significance. We may say that three digits were “lost” in the mapping from -1.0012 to -0.0012. There’s no way the loss could be avoided, regardless of the algorithm, once we decided to round off everything to a fixed number of digits.

Observation 1.2.1 (Subtractive cancellation)

Subtractive cancellation is a loss of accuracy that occurs when two numbers add or subtract to give a result that is much smaller in magnitude. It is one of the most common mechanisms introducing dramatic growth of errors in floating-point computation.

In double precision, all the values are represented to about 16 significant decimal digits of precision, but it’s understood that subtractive cancellation may render some of those digits essentially meaningless.

1.2.1Condition numbers¶

Now we consider problems more generally. As above, we represent a problem as a function fff that maps a real data value xxx to a real result f(x)f(x)f(x). We abbreviate this situation by the notation f:R↦Rf:\real \mapsto \realf:R↦R, where R\realR represents the real number set.

When the problem fff is approximated in floating point on a computer, the data xxx is represented as a floating-point value x~=fl⁡(x)\tilde{x}=\fl(x)x~=fl(x). Ignoring all other sources of error, we define the quantitative measure

∣∣∣f(x)−f(x~)∣∣f(x)∣∣∣∣x−x~∣∣x∣, \frac{ \vphantom{\dfrac{\bigl|}{\bigl|}}\dfrac{|f(x)-f(\tilde{x})|}{|f(x)|} }{% \vphantom{\dfrac{\bigl|}{\bigl|}}\dfrac{|x-\tilde{x}|}{|x|} },∣∣​∣∣​​∣x∣∣x−x~∣​∣∣​∣∣​​∣f(x)∣∣f(x)−f(x~)∣​​,
(1.2.3)

which is the ratio of the relative changes in result and data. We make this expression more convenient if we recall that floating-point arithmetic gives x~=x(1+ϵ)\tilde{x}=x(1+\epsilon)x~=x(1+ϵ) for some value ∣ϵ∣≤ϵmach/2|\epsilon|\le \macheps/2∣ϵ∣≤ϵmach​/2. Hence

∣f(x)−f(x+ϵx)∣∣ϵf(x)∣. \dfrac{\left|f(x)-f(x+\epsilon x)\right| } {|\epsilon f(x)|}.∣ϵf(x)∣∣f(x)−f(x+ϵx)∣​.
(1.2.4)

Finally, we idealize what happens in a perfect computer by taking a limit as ϵmach→0\macheps\to 0ϵmach​→0.

Definition 1.2.1 (Condition number (scalar function))

The relative condition number of a scalar function f(x)f(x)f(x) is

κf(x)=lim⁡ϵ→0∣f(x)−f(x(1+ϵ))∣∣ϵf(x)∣. \kappa_f(x) = \lim_{\epsilon\to 0} \dfrac{ |f(x)-f(x(1+\epsilon))| }{ |\epsilon f(x)| }.κf​(x)=ϵ→0lim​∣ϵf(x)∣∣f(x)−f(x(1+ϵ))∣​.
(1.2.5)

The condition number is a ratio of the relative error of the output to the relative error of the input. It depends only on the problem and the data, not the computer or the algorithm.

Assuming that fff has at least one continuous derivative, we can simplify the expression (1.2.5) through some straightforward manipulations:

κf(x)=lim⁡ϵ→0∣f(x+ϵx)−f(x)ϵf(x)∣=lim⁡ϵ→0∣f(x+ϵx)−f(x)ϵx⋅xf(x)∣=∣xf′(x)f(x)∣.\begin{split} \kappa_f(x) &= \lim_{\epsilon\to 0} \left| \dfrac{ f(x+\epsilon x) - f(x) }{ \epsilon f(x)} \right| \\ &= \lim_{\epsilon\to 0} \left| \dfrac{ f(x+\epsilon x) - f(x) }{ \epsilon x} \cdot \frac{x}{f(x)} \right| \\ &= \left| \dfrac{ x f'(x)} {f(x)} \right|. \end{split}κf​(x)​=ϵ→0lim​∣∣​ϵf(x)f(x+ϵx)−f(x)​∣∣​=ϵ→0lim​∣∣​ϵxf(x+ϵx)−f(x)​⋅f(x)x​∣∣​=∣∣​f(x)xf′(x)​∣∣​.​
(1.2.6)

In retrospect, it should come as no surprise that the change in values of f(x)f(x)f(x) due to small changes in xxx involves the derivative of fff. In fact, if we were making measurements of changes in absolute rather than relative terms, the condition number would be simply ∣f′(x)∣|f'(x)|∣f′(x)∣.

Example 1.2.1

Let’s return to our “add 1” problem and generalize it slightly to f(x)=x−cf(x)=x-cf(x)=x−c for constant ccc. We compute, using (1.2.6),

κf(x)=∣(x)(1)x−c∣=∣xx−c∣.\kappa_f(x)=\left| \frac{(x)(1)}{x-c} \right| = \left| \frac{x}{x-c}\right|.κf​(x)=∣∣​x−c(x)(1)​∣∣​=∣∣​x−cx​∣∣​.
(1.2.7)

The result is the relative change (1.2.2) normalized by the size of the perturbation ε. The condition number is large when ∣x∣≫∣x−c∣|x|\gg |x-c|∣x∣≫∣x−c∣. Considering that ccc can be negative, this result applies to both addition and subtraction. Furthermore, the situation is symmetric in xxx and ccc; that is, if we perturbed ccc and not xxx, the result would be ∣c∣/∣x−c∣|c|/|x-c|∣c∣/∣x−c∣.

Example 1.2.2

Another elementary operation is to multiply by a constant: f(x)=cxf(x)=cxf(x)=cx for nonzero ccc. We compute

κf(x)=∣xf′(x)f(x)∣=∣(x)(c)cx∣=1.\kappa_f(x) = \left| \dfrac{ x f'(x)} {f(x)} \right| = \left| \frac{(x)(c)}{cx} \right| = 1.κf​(x)=∣∣​f(x)xf′(x)​∣∣​=∣∣​cx(x)(c)​∣∣​=1.
(1.2.8)

We conclude that multiplication by a real number leads to the same relative error in the result as in the data. In other words, multiplication does not have the potential for cancellation error that addition does.

Condition numbers of the major elementary functions are given in Table 1.2.1.

As you are asked to show in Exercise 1.2.4, when two functions fff and ggg are combined in a chain as h(x)=f(g(x))h(x)=f(g(x))h(x)=f(g(x)), the composite condition number is

κh(x)=κf(g(x))⋅κg(x).\kappa_h(x) = \kappa_f(g(x)) \cdot \kappa_g(x).κh​(x)=κf​(g(x))⋅κg​(x).
(1.2.9)

1.2.2Estimating errors¶

Refer back to the definition of κf\kappa_fκf​ as a limit in (1.2.5). Approximately speaking, if ∣ϵ∣|\epsilon|∣ϵ∣ is small, we expect

∣f(x+ϵx)−f(x)f(x)∣≈κf(x) ∣ϵ∣.\left| \dfrac{ f(x+\epsilon x) - f(x) }{ f(x)} \right| \approx \kappa_f(x)\, |\epsilon|.∣∣​f(x)f(x+ϵx)−f(x)​∣∣​≈κf​(x)∣ϵ∣.
(1.2.10)

That is, whenever the data xxx is perturbed by a small amount, we expect that relative perturbation to be magnified by a factor of κf(x)\kappa_f(x)κf​(x) in the result.

Observation 1.2.2

If κf≈10d\kappa_f \approx 10^dκf​≈10d, then we expect to lose up to ddd decimal digits of accuracy in computing f(x)f(x)f(x) from xxx.

Large condition numbers signal when errors cannot be expected to remain comparable in size to roundoff error. We call a problem poorly conditioned or ill-conditioned when κf(x)\kappa_f(x)κf​(x) is large, although there is no fixed threshold for the term.

If κf≈1/ϵmach\kappa_f \approx 1/\machepsκf​≈1/ϵmach​, then we can expect the result to have a relative error of as much as 100% simply by expressing the data xxx in finite precision. Such a function is essentially not computable at this machine epsilon.

Example 1.2.3

Consider the problem f(x)=cos⁡(x)f(x)= \cos(x)f(x)=cos(x). By the table above, κf(x)=∣xtan⁡x∣\kappa_f(x) = |x \tan x|κf​(x)=∣xtanx∣. There are two different ways in which κ might become large:

  • If ∣x∣|x|∣x∣ is very large, then perturbations that are small relative to xxx may still be large compared to 1. Because ∣f(x)∣≤1|f(x)|\le 1∣f(x)∣≤1 for all xxx, this implies that the perturbation will be large relative to the result, too.
  • The condition number grows without bound as xxx approaches an odd integer multiple of π/2\pi/2π/2, where f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0. A perturbation which is small relative to a nonzero xxx may not be small relative to f(x)f(x)f(x) in such a case.

You may have noticed that for some functions, such as the square root, the condition number can be less than 1. This means that relative changes get smaller in the passage from input to output. However, every result in floating-point arithmetic is still subject to rounding error at the relative level of ϵmach\machepsϵmach​. In practice, κf<1\kappa_f<1κf​<1 is no different from κf=1\kappa_f=1κf​=1.

1.2.3Polynomial roots¶

Most problems have multiple input and output values. These introduce complications into the formal definition of the condition number. Rather than worry over those details here, we can still look at variations in only one output value with respect to one data value at a time.

Example 1.2.4

Consider the problem of finding the roots of a quadratic polynomial; that is, the values of ttt for which at2+bt+c=0at^2+bt+c=0at2+bt+c=0. Here the data are the coefficients aaa, bbb, and ccc that define the polynomial, and the solution to the problem are the two (maybe complex-valued) roots r1r_1r1​ and r2r_2r2​. Formally, we might write f([a,b,c])=[r1,r2]f([a,b,c])=[r_1,r_2]f([a,b,c])=[r1​,r2​] using vector notation.

Let’s pick one root r1r_1r1​ and consider what happens to it as we vary just the leading coefficient aaa. This suggests a scalar function f(a)=r1f(a)=r_1f(a)=r1​. Starting from ar12+br1+c=0ar_1^2 + br_1 + c = 0ar12​+br1​+c=0, we differentiate implicitly with respect to aaa while holding bbb and ccc fixed:

r12+2ar1(dr1da)+b dr1da=0.r_1^2 + 2a r_1 \left(\frac{dr_1}{da}\right) + b \,\frac{dr_1}{da} = 0.r12​+2ar1​(dadr1​​)+bdadr1​​=0.
(1.2.11)

Solving for the derivative, we obtain

dr1da=−r122ar1+b.\frac{dr_1}{da} = \frac{-r_1^2}{2a r_1 + b}.dadr1​​=2ar1​+b−r12​​.
(1.2.12)

Hence the condition number for the problem f(a)=r1f(a)=r_1f(a)=r1​ is

κf(a)=∣ar1⋅dr1da∣=∣ar12ar1+b∣=∣r1r1−r2∣,\kappa_f(a) = \left|\frac{a}{r_1} \cdot \frac{dr_1}{da} \right| = \left| \frac{a r_1}{ 2a r_1 + b} \right| = \left| \frac{r_1}{ r_1-r_2} \right|,κf​(a)=∣∣​r1​a​⋅dadr1​​∣∣​=∣∣​2ar1​+bar1​​∣∣​=∣∣​r1​−r2​r1​​∣∣​,
(1.2.13)

where in the last step we used the quadratic formula:

∣2ar1+b∣=∣b2−4ac ∣=∣a(r1−r2)∣.|2ar_1 + b | = \left| \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \, \right| = |a(r_1 - r_2)|.∣2ar1​+b∣=∣∣​b2−4ac​∣∣​=∣a(r1​−r2​)∣.
(1.2.14)

Based on (1.2.13), we can expect poor conditioning in the rootfinding problem if and only if ∣r1∣≫∣r1−r2∣|r_1| \gg |r_1-r_2|∣r1​∣≫∣r1​−r2​∣. Similar conclusions apply for r2r_2r2​ and for variations with respect to the coefficients bbb and ccc.

The calculation in Example 1.2.4 generalizes to polynomials of higher degree.

Observation 1.2.3

Roots of polynomials are ill-conditioned with respect to changes in the polynomial coefficients when they are much closer to each other than to the origin.

The condition number of a root can be arbitrarily large. In the extreme case of a repeated root, the condition number is formally infinite, which implies that the ratio of changes in the root to changes in the coefficients cannot be bounded.

Example 1.2.5 (Conditioning of polynomial roots)

Example 1.2.5

The polynomial p(x)=13(x−1)(x−1−ϵ)p(x) = \frac{1}{3}(x-1)(x-1-\epsilon)p(x)=31​(x−1)(x−1−ϵ) has roots 1 and 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ. For small values of ε, the roots are ill-conditioned.

Tip

The statement x,y = 10,20 makes individual assignments to both x and y.

ϵ = 1e-6   # type \epsilon and then press Tab
a,b,c = 1/3,(-2-ϵ)/3,(1+ϵ)/3   # coefficients of p
(0.3333333333333333, -0.666667, 0.33333366666666664)

Here are the roots as computed by the quadratic formula.

d = sqrt(b^2 - 4a*c)
r₁ = (-b - d) / (2a)   # type r\_1 and then press Tab
r₂ = (-b + d) / (2a)
(r₁, r₂)
(0.9999999998251499, 1.0000010001748503)

The relative errors in these values are

@show abs(r₁ - 1) / abs(1);
@show abs(r₂ - (1+ϵ)) / abs(1+ϵ);
abs(r₁ - 1) / abs(1) = 1.7485013437124053e-10
abs(r₂ - (1 + ϵ)) / abs(1 + ϵ) = 1.748501815656639e-10

The condition number of each root is

κ(ri)=∣ri∣∣r1−r2∣≈1ϵ.\kappa(r_i) = \frac{|r_i|}{|r_1-r_2|} \approx \frac{1}{\epsilon}.κ(ri​)=∣r1​−r2​∣∣ri​∣​≈ϵ1​.
(1)

Thus, relative error in the data at the level of roundoff can grow in the result to be roughly

eps() / ϵ
2.220446049250313e-10

This matches the observation pretty well.
